text: So by and large I would say end of the day, we look at the global crisises and we say, "Oh, this is going to impact an industry." But as an entrepreneur, you don't care about the industry, you care about your own startup, that's it. And if the rest of the world is suffering from the same problem, doesn't help you, not even a single bit.
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Lenny asks Uri about how global crises like COVID affected startups, using Uri's restaurant reservation platform Order.chat as an example. Uri explains that while many companies failed during COVID, entrepreneurs shouldn't take comfort in industry-wide problems. He emphasizes that founders must focus solely on their own company's survival rather than finding solace in the fact that competitors are also struggling.
text_ko: 결국 정리하자면, 우리는 전 세계적인 위기(global crises)를 보며 '아, 이게 어느 업계(industry)에 영향을 주겠구나'라고 말하죠. 그런데 창업가(entrepreneur) 입장에서는 업계는 신경 안 쓰고 자기 스타트업(startup)만 신경 써요, 그게 전부예요. 그리고 세상이 다 같은 문제로 고통받는다고 해도, 그건 자기한테 아무 도움이 되지 않아요, 조금도요.
text_zh: 总的来说，我觉得最终来看，我们看到全球危机的时候会说"哦，这会影响整个行业"。但作为创业者，你根本不在乎什么行业，你只在乎你自己的初创公司(startup)，就这么简单。全世界其他人都遇到同样的问题，对你一点用都没有，一丁点儿帮助都没有。
text_es: En general, yo diría que al final del día, vemos las crisis globales y decimos "Ay, esto va a impactar toda la industria." Pero como emprendedor, te vale madre la industria - perdón por la expresión - te importa tu propia startup y ya. Y si el resto del mundo está sufriendo el mismo problema, no te ayuda para nada, ni tantito.

text: So two types of, abstractly, two types of crisis. One is that I would call that a cash crisis. So all of a sudden your cash program or plan is being jeopardized, for losing a customer, disappearing investor, not meeting your expectation, dramatic price change in the market and so forth. And the other one is lose of product market fit.
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Lenny asks Uri to create a taxonomy of the different types of crises that founders face. Uri breaks down the major existential threats into two categories: cash crises (when your funding or revenue streams are suddenly at risk) and product-market fit crises (when your product becomes irrelevant). He explains that cash crises involve financial pressures like losing customers or investors, while product-market fit loss means you need to start over completely.
text_ko: 추상적으로 보면 위기는 크게 두 가지예요. 하나는 제가 '자금 위기(cash crisis)'라고 부르는 건데, 예를 들어 갑자기 고객을 잃거나 투자자가 떠나거나 기대에 못 미치거나 시장에서 가격이 급격히 변해서 현금 흐름이나 자금 운영 계획이 위태로워지는 상황이에요. 다른 하나는 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 잃는 거예요.
text_zh: 抽象来说，有两种危机。一种我叫它现金危机，就是突然间你的现金流计划出了问题，可能是丢了大客户、投资人跑了、业绩没达到预期，或者市场价格大幅波动什么的。另一种就是产品和市场不匹配了，失去了product market fit。
text_es: Entonces hay dos tipos de crisis, hablando en abstracto. Una que yo llamaría crisis de liquidez o de caja. De repente tu programa de flujo de efectivo o tu plan se ve amenazado, ya sea por perder un cliente importante, que desaparezca un inversionista, no cumplir tus expectativas, un cambio drástico de precios en el mercado, y cosas así. Y la otra es la pérdida del product market fit.

text: Never give up is the most important behavior of successful CEOs of startup. The second one, by the way, is making decisions with conviction. If you don't make them with conviction, then the team is not going to follow. If the team is not going to follow, then you are not going to be successful.
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Lenny asks Uri about his advice to never give up during a crisis. Uri explains the two most critical behaviors for startup CEOs: persistence and decisive leadership. He emphasizes that making decisions with conviction is essential because team members need to see strong leadership to maintain their commitment, especially during difficult times when uncertainty could cause talented people to leave the company.
text_ko: 성공한 스타트업(startup)의 최고경영자(CEO)들에게 가장 중요한 행동은 절대 포기하지 않는 거예요. 두 번째로 중요한 건 확신(conviction)을 가지고 결정을 내리는 거예요. 확신 없이 결정을 하면 팀이 따라오지 않고, 팀이 따라오지 않으면 결국 성공하기 어렵거든요.
text_zh: 对于创业公司的CEO来说，永不放弃是成功最重要的品质。第二个呢，就是要有魄力地做决策。如果你做决定的时候犹犹豫豫的，团队就不会跟着你走。团队都不跟你，那你肯定做不成事儿。
text_es: Nunca rendirse es lo más importante que tienen que hacer los CEOs exitosos de startups. Lo segundo, por cierto, es tomar decisiones con convicción. Si no las tomas con convicción, entonces el equipo no te va a seguir. Y si el equipo no te sigue, no vas a tener éxito.

text: At the end of the day, you cannot rely on someone else, you have only one company, you need to make sure that this company is successful. When you assume responsibility, you're basically saying, "You know what, I control my own destiny."
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Lenny discusses Uri's philosophy that founders must take complete responsibility for their company's success or failure, even when external factors are involved. Uri explains why founders shouldn't blame market conditions or other external circumstances for their failures. He argues that taking full responsibility empowers founders to believe they can control their outcomes and increases their likelihood of success.
vocabulary_highlights: at the end of the day
text_ko: 결국 다른 사람한테 기대할 수는 없어요. 여러분에겐 단 하나의 회사뿐이니 그 회사를 성공시키는 건 여러분의 몫이에요. 책임을 진다는 건 사실상 "있잖아요, 내 운명은 내가 결정해요"라고 말하는 거예요.
text_zh: 说到底，你不能指望别人，你就这么一家公司，必须确保它能成功。当你承担起责任的时候，其实就是在说："我的命运我做主。"
text_es: Al final del día, no puedes depender de otra persona, solo tienes una empresa, y tienes que asegurarte de que esa empresa sea exitosa. Cuando asumes la responsabilidad, básicamente estás diciendo: "¿Sabes qué? Yo controlo mi propio destino."

text: The longer that you wait, you actually lose options. The only ability to choose is today. This is one of the most challenging part of a crisis. You actually need to make a decision rapidly, like today.
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Lenny asks about the importance of acting quickly during a crisis. Uri is explaining why founders must make difficult decisions immediately when facing a cash crisis. Using a mathematical example of runway extension, he demonstrates how delaying cost-cutting decisions by even a few months can eliminate the founder's ability to extend their runway to the desired length, making speed of decision-making critical for startup survival.
text_ko: 더 오래 기다릴수록 선택권이 줄어들어요. 선택할 수 있는 건 오늘뿐이에요. 위기에서는 이게 가장 어려운 부분 중 하나예요. 실제로는 오늘처럼 빠르게 결정을 내려야 해요.
text_zh: 你拖得越久，选择就越少。能做决定的机会就是现在。这就是危机最难的地方——你必须快速做决定，就是今天。
text_es: Mientras más tiempo esperes, en realidad vas perdiendo opciones. La única oportunidad real de elegir es hoy. Esta es una de las partes más difíciles de una crisis. Necesitas tomar la decisión rápido, como que ya.

text: If you are in the middle of it and you ask yourself, so what are the chances that we will end up being successful? It looks way smaller. Way smaller. So what happened here is that you realize that, okay, this is not forever, so ski is going to come back but we don't know how long and therefore we assume that it's going to be for two seasons until it's coming back, until 2022.
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Uri is describing how his ski vacation booking company WeSki survived the COVID crisis. When the pandemic shut down European ski resorts, the company faced potential bankruptcy since they were supposed to become profitable that year. Uri explains how the team had to make assumptions about how long the crisis would last and plan accordingly, even though success seemed unlikely when they were in the thick of the crisis.
text_ko: 그 상황 한가운데에 있을 때 스스로 '우리가 결국 성공할 가능성은 얼마나 될까?' 하고 물어보면, 가능성은 훨씬 작아 보여요. 훨씬 작아요. 그래서 여기서 벌어진 일은 '아, 이건 영원히 계속되는 게 아니구나'라고 깨닫게 된다는 거예요. 스키는 다시 돌아오겠지만 언제일지는 모르니까 다시 돌아올 때까지 두 시즌 정도, 그러니까 2022년까지 계속될 거라고 가정하게 되는 거예요.
text_zh: 当你身处其中的时候，你会问自己，我们成功的几率到底有多大？看起来真的很渺茫，非常渺茫。所以这时候你就意识到，好吧，这种情况不会永远持续下去，滑雪产业肯定会回来的，但我们不知道要多久，所以我们假设可能要两个雪季才能恢复，也就是要到2022年。
text_es: Si estás en pleno proceso y te preguntas, ¿cuáles son las posibilidades de que al final tengamos éxito? Se ve mucho más difícil. Muchísimo más difícil. Entonces lo que pasó aquí es que te das cuenta de que, bueno, esto no es para siempre, el esquí va a regresar pero no sabemos cuándo y por eso asumimos que va a ser por dos temporadas hasta que regrese, hasta 2022.

text: During crisis, people will appreciate more than anything else transparency. And if you hide information from them, then they would leave, they don't trust you anymore. But if there is a crisis, and look, if there is a crisis then everyone knows that there is a crisis, it's not surprising for anyone.
speaker: Uri Levine
context: Lenny asks Uri for advice on keeping team members motivated and engaged during a crisis. Uri emphasizes the critical importance of transparent communication with employees during difficult times. He explains that hiding bad news from the team will backfire because people can sense when something is wrong, and dishonesty will cause them to lose trust and leave the company when you need them most.
text_ko: 위기 상황에서는 무엇보다 투명성(transparency)을 가장 높게 평가해요. 정보를 숨기면 사람들은 떠나고 더 이상 신뢰하지 않아요. 어차피 위기가 닥치면 모두가 그 사실을 알고 있어서 누구에게도 놀랄 일이 아니에요.
text_zh: 遇到危机的时候，大家最看重的就是透明度。你要是藏着掖着不告诉他们实情，人家就会走人，再也不信任你了。但是如果真的出了危机，你想想，既然出了危机，那大家肯定都知道有问题，这也不是什么意外的事儿。
text_es: Durante una crisis, la gente va a valorar más que nada la transparencia. Y si les ocultas información, entonces se van a ir, ya no confían en ti. Pero si hay una crisis, y mira, si hay una crisis entonces todo el mundo sabe que hay una crisis, no es ninguna sorpresa para nadie.
